text:

crucial for risk management; by enabling risk awareness, risk mitigation, and risk-based decision 
making. 
A variety of risk assessment methods exist, across many industries [1], [2]. These methods all 
have the same basic steps in common: Determine what can go wrong1.
Determine how often this happens2.
Determine the extent of the consequences3.
Determine if the assessed risk is acceptable4. Methods to perform the risk assessment vary widely across industry domains. Furthermore, even 
within the same domain, the risk assessment can take different forms which may differ in 
dimension. A primary driver of model design is the desired output: Will risk be expressed as a 
numerical value as a function of probability? Or will the risk be expressed as a qualitative term 
expressed linguistically or as a relative index on a normalized rating scale? This first design 
decision drives the selection of model expression (quantitative versus rule-based), and model 
inputs (quantitative versus qualitative data).
Regardless of methodology, risk is the probability of an undesired outcome with the severity of 
that outcome. Risk (R) is the Probability (P) of Severity (S) Risk Assessment Model Dimensions / Evaluation Criteria2.1
In evaluating risk modeling for airworthiness assessments, there are several dimensions along 
which comparisons may be made, as indicated in the following list. There is no order or 
weighting of these criteria. Nor are these criteria the only basis for the final recommendation. How is the risk model expressed? 
What kind of input data feeds the approach?
What kind of output is produced? Additional metrics for model implementation evaluation include: Complexity of model
Intended use (as designed)
Decision support automation
Risk areas covered Risk to pedestrians on the ground-
Risk to other aircraft- ii
 Risk of penetration of sensitive/restricted areas-
Risk due to human error (whether in planning, controlling, responding to -
unforeseen/adverse conditions) Model Expression2.1.1
Model expression refers to the formalism used to encode the risk computation. This may take the 
form of fault and event trees [3], [4], mathematical formulations [5], risk matrices [6], rule-based 
approach [7], or some combination of these and others [8]. Choice of representation is dependent 
on intended use and available data. 
Quantitative models enable rapid exploration of input parameters. Trials (what-if tests) are easy 
and inexpensive to run, replicate, and quantify. Probabilistic distributions of input parameters can 
be randomly sampled to explore the interactions among inputs, and results (e.g., most likely 
output).
Qualitative models emphasize representation of a maximal set of risk factors. Presentation of 
numerical input and output of a model may take various formats such as formulas, look-up tables, 
flow charts, and risk matrices. The rules which combine inputs are typically knowledge-driven, 
meaning that they are derived from subject matter expert knowledge elicitation instead of 
formulas. Input Data2.1.2
Risk models vary in their data requirements. Input data can range from precise quantification of 
risk factor probabilities and probabilistic distributions to subjective assessments, expressed on a 
numerical scale, or a descriptive term (such as low and high). For example, the probability of 
a component failure may be expressed quantitatively as a point probability (e.g., 110-5) or as a 
probabilistic function (e.g., a normal distribution around a mean value). A qualitative reliability 
input may be expressed as very reliable.
Quantitative models will depend on quantitative data to compute a quantitative output, while 
qualitative or non-numerical data can be used only by qualitative methods (e.g., rule-based 
models). Outputs2.1.3
Risk model output is motivated by demands of the assessment problem and constrained by the 
modeling methodology and input data. Methods which produce a quantitative expression of the 
severity of a hazard, in conjunction with its probability of occurrence, are referred to as 
quantitative methods.
Interpretation of a quantitative risk model output, probability of severity, is straightforward. For 
example, probability of an adverse effect during a particular time period, such as probability of 
sUAS failures in one flight hour. Severity in this example relates sUAS failures to fatalities. 
Quantitative models can be validated over time based on actual event statistics, however, this is 
problematic for rare events. As a substitute, the input probability of relatively more common 
adverse events can be refined (e.g., motor failure). The model algorithm, how output is calculated 
based on input, can also be challenged and reevaluated by various researchers until a safe 
consensus is achieved. 
Quantitative modeling can use both statistical and deterministic parameters to represent real iii
 world situations. These values can be presented in various formats such as graphs, equations, 
diagrams, scatterplots, and tree diagrams. The model provides an abstraction that reduces a 
problem to its essential characteristics. The model describes, in a quantifiable way, the impact of 
the inputs on the output. Inputs represent parameters which can be determined, measured, or 
described probabilistically and the output is similarly numerical or probabilistic. 
Quantitative risk assessment is sometimes also known as probabilistic risk assessment. The goal 
is to use quantitative data (measurable, comparable) to support an evaluation whose result is a 
calculated expression of the severity of a hazard in conjunction with its probability of occurrence. 
There are various understandings and definitions of risk. [2], [9]. 
Probabilistic risk assessment uses data to develop a probability distribution of risk. This enables 
the evaluation of input data variability and uncertainty and its effect on the risk assessment. Strengths and Weakness of Quantitative Modeling2.1.4
The openly shared algorithm is the main strength of a quantitative approach to risk assessment. Increased model clarity: inputs and outputs are explicit
Comparability
Repeatability
Automation, modeling and simulation A risk model which shares its algorithm description is clear and comprehensible in the sense that 
it specifies exactly how the inputs of the model are determined or measured. The formal 
expression relating the input parameters to the output can be verified by other researchers. 
For the same inputs, the model will always generate the same output. Because of this 
consistency, it is easy to compare model outputs under different conditions. Changes in output 
are due only to changes in measurable input variables. Finally, a quantitative model with a clearly 
defined range of determined or measured inputs is programmable and can be run automatically to 
support various modeling and simulation strategies, such as Monte Carlo methods.
In contrast, the weaknesses of quantitative modeling are: The quality of the output is only as good as the quality of the input
Narrower scope of available features, since data is required to support probabilities
It may ignore some important qualitative (non-quantifiable) differences for simplicity
It may blur a desired distinction between high probability, low severity events, and low 
probability, high severity events (which may have the same risk score) A qualitative feature must be given a scale of numeric values (e.g., 1= Strongly Agree, 5= 
Strongly Disagree). Not all qualitative features are amenable to this mapping, which can restrict 
the inputs. As such, in situations where the process to be modeled is incompletely understood or 
specified, model expressivity is lost and the model will be incomplete. Assumptions may be 
needed to fill in the unquantifiable aspects. Reducing a complex process into a simple equation 
may risk losing important distinctions. For example, events A and B may appear to have equal 
risk, when the product of the high likelihood and low severity of event A may be equal to the low 
severity and high likelihood of event B. iv
 Knowledge-Driven Risk Assessment2.2
In a knowledge-driven system, risk inference methods are based on variables, rules, and 
relationships derived from subject matter experts. Although a qualitative process may be 
formalized and rigorous, it does not necessarily require a precise algorithm. The dominant feature 
of such models is that input data may be qualitative, reflecting inputs which are not measurable 
quantities, and output is qualitative. Output may be a risk classification, or relative risk index on 
some scale (such as 1 to 10). Qualitative inference methods may include matrices relating 
likelihood categories and severity categories to risk, such as the FAAs safety system 
management (SMS) risk matrix [6]. Other methods include event and fault trees, rule-based 
systems, and various combinations of such methods. Strengths and Weaknesses of Knowledge-Driven Assessment2.2.1
The risk value inference process is a logical and repeatable process, which can consider a very 
broad range of risk and mitigation factors. For instance, in the SORA process, the guidance 
indicates that more than 100 inputs are required for the risk assessment. At least 40 of the 
requisite inputs are quantifiable, measurable parameters, such as aircraft dimensions and mass. 
Other inputs are qualitative (e.g., high/medium/low) and free text (e.g., name of aircraft design 
organization). 
The breadth of inputs required for SORA indicate the span of the risk assessment. If a system is 
manufactured by a well-established company and undergoes regular maintenance and 
configuration management, the risk may be assessed to be less than for a new applicant.
A knowledge-driven risk assessment is generally more labor-intensive and complex. There are a 
series of required steps, most of which are manually derived. Although the model is a logical and 
repeatable process, the complexity of input parameters entails a significant amount of subjectivity 
by the assessor. i
 Risk Modeling for Small UAS Airworthiness Assessment3
